Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Risk and Resilience Post-Hurricane Harvey: A Longitudinal Examination of Pre-Disaster Sleep in Youth

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports research on children affected by Hurricane Harvey. This research project will examine how Hurricane Harvey and events surrounding the hurricane impacted children's development, particularly children's sleep patterns. Children are especially vulnerable to traumatic events. This project will enhance the ability to identify youth at the highest levels of risk both before and after a natural disaster. It will also provide information about how children react to trauma and how their development is impacted by trauma. The study will have broader impacts, because results will likely help local officials, schools, and parents in disaster-prone communities reduce the long-term effects of catastrophic events on children.

Prior research on adults shows that certain sleep patterns either elevate or buffer against psychological risk in the face of a disaster. Little is known about the connections between natural disasters, trauma, sleep, and psychological risk among children. This project will include a sample of youth living in the Houston, Texas metropolitan area during Hurricane Harvey. Those youth completed a comprehensive assessment of sleep and psychological functioning prior to Hurricane Harvey. The current study will take advantage of those data collected before the hurricane. This study will enable data to be collected after the hurricane, which will give investigators the ability to compare pre- and post-hurricane social, emotional, behavioral, and academic functioning using parent, teacher, and youth reports. Researchers will examine whether the presence of certain sleep patterns and features, exhibited by children prior to Hurricane Harvey, decreases or increases risk of poor social, behavioral, emotional, and academic functioning. The primary hypothesis is that pre-disaster sleep characterized by (a) less total and more fragmented REM (rapid eye movement) sleep periods; (b) less slow wave sleep; (c) less sleep spindle activity; and (d) longer sleep onset latency, will amplify the negative effects of hurricane exposure on social, behavioral, emotional, and academic functioning. Emotional functioning will be assessed using subjective reports as well as psychophysiology (electrodermal activity, respiratory sinus arrhythmia). Families will also complete a semi-structured diagnostic clinical interview to assess for psychiatric diagnoses. This study has the potential to inform models of trauma. This study will help the general public better understand the impact natural disasters have on children. This proposal is appropriate for the NSF RAPID mechanism because the ephemeral nature of the data to be collected means there is an urgency to the project. The ability to begin collecting data as soon as possible is crucial.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Dr. Cara Palmer has completed research for the project: Risk and Resilience Post-Hurricane Harvey: A Longitudinal Examination of Pre-Disaster Sleep in Youth. This project was supported by a NSF Rapid Response Grant. The purpose of the project was to examine neurophysiological and behavioral aspects of sleep in childhood prior to Hurricane Harvey in forecasting social, behavioral, emotional, and academic functioning posthurricane. Prior research on adults shows that certain sleep patterns either elevate or buffer against psychological risk in the face of a disaster. Little is known about the connections between natural disasters, trauma, sleep, and psychological risk among children.

The proposed study capitalized on a previously-recruited, racially/ethnically diverse cohort of children who completed comprehensive assessments of sleep and socio-emotional functioning in childhood (7 to 11 years) and who were living in the Houston, TX metropolitan area during Hurricane Harvey.  The majority of these children lived in neighborhoods along waterways that experienced flooding during Hurricane Harvey. At Time 1, participants completed comprehensive assessments of sleep (subjective reports and objective measures including actigraphy and polysomnography) and social and emotional funcitoning. Our specific objectives of this work included recruiting the final sample, data processing, and data analysis. All specific objectives have been met. We successfully collected data from 71 participants for our post-hurricane assessment in the 6-9 months after Hurricane Harvey. During the post-hurricane assessment, children completed parent and child questionnaires to assess social, behavioral, and academic functioning, a diagnostic clinical interview, and a task to assess subjective, psychophysiological, and behavioral reactivity to hurricane-related imagery. Waking salivary cortisol and actigraphy-measured sleep were assessed for one week. Finally, teachers also provided reports of academic, social, and behavioral functioning.

Findings suggest that in the 6-9 months after the hurricane, the majority of children (75%) reported at least some emotional difficulty related to Harvey. Children with more exposure to hurricane-related stressors (e.g., displacement, loss of personal property) had poorer functioning post-hurricane, even when controlling for pre-hurricane symptoms and demographic characteristics (including age, gender, socioeconomic status). The negative effects of these hurricane stressors were strengthed for those who had poor sleep patterns prior to the hurricane. To our knowledge, this is the first study to examine how sleep prior to a trauma affects post-disaster functioning in a pediatric sample. Overall, these findings suggest that specific sleep patterns prior to exposure to a natural disaster were associated with increased vulnerability in the aftermath of the disaster, even when accouting for demographic characteristics and pre-existing emotional symptoms.

This project also provided valuable training and research opportunities for students. Students gained experience in longitudinal data collection procedures and recruitment, diagnostic clinical interviews, and in the processing of data. This project has also provided opportunities for student publications and presentations. The majority of these students were from underrepresented groups (84% female and 56% racial or ethnic minority students), many were from low-income backgrounds, and 3 students were military veterans.

As natural disasters are predicted to become more frequent and severe, findings from the current study advance our understanding of risk for long-term negative adjustment. Children are especially vulnerable to traumatic events, and strategies for mitigating the effects of natural disasters on various aspects of youth development are critically needed. Findings from the current study inform how we can identify youth at the highest levels of risk prior to, during, and in the aftermath of natural disasters. It also provides information about how children react to trauma and how their development is impacted by trauma. Results from this study suggest that promoting healthy sleep in children can promote psychological resilience and can reduce the long-term effects of catastrophic events on children.
